none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, June 4, 1882
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, June 4, 1882
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 12 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]

Bonham Texas.
June 4th 1882.

My Dear Professor:
Your good letter
recd read & enjoyed. I fear that
I shall be unable to meet you
at Hempstead on Friday 16th.
Our Trustees will hold, - according
to custom - their Annual meeting
at 10 A.M. Saturday 17th. My Annual
report will be due & called for at
that hour. I could return at
12 M. on Saturday. If possible I
will meet you at place suggested
but the chances are against
me. Besides, our sermon will
be preached on Sabbath & I shall
be full of business until
the close of the public Exercises.
Nothing but dire necessity
will prevent me from seeing you -
I was so much in hopes to
see you at Tyler. I have
some business matters there &
expect to leave for Tyler via

**Comprehensive Transcription of Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break down this task. My immediate goal is to accurately transcribe this handwritten letter from Bonham, Texas, June 4th, 1882. It's in cursive, the ink is purple/blue, and it's on lined paper, although the lines are faint. I'll need to capture the exact words while paying close attention to the formatting, capitalization, and any peculiar letter formations – because those details often carry historical significance. I'll need to use the permitted HTML tags as the instructions dictate.

First, I'll identify and label structural elements like the header, salutation, and body, being mindful of the formatting (right-aligned header, etc.) and line breaks, using allowed HTML tags. I'll meticulously transcribe the body, noting any potential ambiguities. For instance, the word after "letter" looks like "recd," but the last letter looks like "u", so I must read it within the context, so this must be "recd". The abbreviation "12 M." for noon and will be written as "12. M." with a period as it is clearer from the image. Superscripts like "th" will be preserved using `<sup>`.

I'll check the transcription against the image multiple times for accuracy, paying close attention to any potentially unusual letter formations or scribbles. I'll deal with any possible contractions, and abbreviations that were common in the late 19th century. Then, I'll review and double-check, looking for any inconsistencies or errors and ensuring all instructions are followed. I need to be precise, I can't guess!

Then, I'll finalize the transcription, incorporating the formatting as required by the guidelines. "My Dear Professor:" seems to be the salutation. The letter's content seems to be about the writer's inability to meet the professor at a specific time, due to trustees' meetings and other commitments. There's a mention of Hempstead, Friday 16th, Tyler, and a Sabbath sermon, which gives the impression of a busy schedule. The tone is apologetic, conveying regret at the missed opportunity to meet. Overall, it's a courteous letter with practical content that needs a careful and thorough transcription.

[1882, June 4]          2

Corsicana on Thursday eve 22–
I want to see Gov. Hubbard &
other friends in Eastern Texas
relative to my making application
for Chair of Ancient Languages
in the University – I see that
Dr Rambaut A M. D.D. LL.D. was
in Austin some days ago.
Prospecting no doubt. I learn
also that Gen. D. H Hill wishes
a place – Our quondam Prof. H.
of course will go to Austin & camp
about 1st of Aug. If Hubbard
were on the Board I should
make application with but
little hesitancy – as it is, I am
without a personal acquaintance
in the Regency – At your
Commencement you will have
an opportunity to gather some
facts & surmises. If you can
gather any thing favorable or un-
favorable to my aspirations, let
me have it with your advise.
I do not think that a full faculty

**Transcription and Analysis of a Letter Fragment**

Alright, let's break this down. It appears I'm looking at a handwritten letter, page two judging by the "2" at the top, dated June 4, 1882, according to the penciled annotation. The writing is in faded purple ink, a clear cursive style of the late 19th century.

The main content seems to be a continuation of a prior letter, as indicated by the "2". The writer, presumably me, is planning a trip, or already made a trip, to Corsicana on Thursday evening, the 22nd. The date is a possible future plan, as the letter is marked June 4, 1882 and the 22nd of June, 1882 was a Thursday. The primary focus of this letter is on pursuing a position, specifically the "Chair of Ancient Languages in the University."

The plan is to meet with Governor Hubbard and other connections in Eastern Texas. This is "relative to my making application" for that "Chair." Apparently, I'm aware of Dr. Rambaut being in Austin recently, and am speculating on his activities. I also gather that General D. H. Hill is also interested in a position. Furthermore, it seems that our "quondam Prof. H." (meaning "former," a Latin term commonly used in those circles) will be headed to Austin "about 1st of Aug," presumably around August 1st. I observe that if Hubbard was on the "Board" (likely the Board of Regents), I would apply without hesitation. However, since I lack personal connections within the "Regency" (the governing body), I need some assistance.

I'm hoping to get some information. The recipient is attending a "Commencement" and I am asking them to gather any "facts & surmises" on how I would be viewed as an applicant, for either "favorable or un-favorable" details that might help my "aspirations," so that you can offer me your "advise." My implication is that a full faculty are currently missing.

[1882, June 4]                                         3 Can or will be provided for at the opening of the Univ. - but certainly the Chain of Ancient Languages will be among the first provided for. I suppose no changes are contemplated in your Faculty. For the next two weeks I shall be oppressed with work + responsibility + before the close I expect I shall long for a "Cot in a vast wilderness". Nat. Teachers Association, I think, will meet at Saratoga a 10th July. Is Prof. J. H. Ranton mentioned in Hollingsworths Journal for May - the J. H. Ranson we knew at U. M. C.? If so he is now at Colgates N.Y. Judge Leland - I suppose - will be our next Gov. As far as I know he is a good & pure man. I shall hear from you again before your Commencement Closes - if I am unable to see you at H. The phenomenal weather has kept me almost sick for some weeks. Let me hear from you soon Your friend                                                   J. T. Hand

**Detailed Transcription & Interpretation of a Handwritten Letter** Okay, here's what I've got from the image. It's a handwritten letter, looks like from around 1882, written in purple ink on lined paper, with a pencil date at the top: `[1882, June 4]` and page number `3`. I'm treating it like a technical task, going line by line, trying to figure out all the words, preserving the original spelling and punctuation, even when it’s a bit unusual. My primary focus is on accuracy here. So, let's start:

[1882, June 4] 3

Can or will be provided for at
the opening of the Univ. - but certainly
the Chain of Ancient Languages
will be among the first provided for.
I suppose no changes are contemplated
in your Faculty. For the next two
weeks I shall be oppressed with
work + responsibility + before the close
I expect I shall long for a "Cot
in a vast wilderness".

Nat. Teachers Association, I think,
will meet at Saratoga a 10th July.
Is Prof. J. H. Ranton mentioned in
Hollingsworths Journal for May -
the J. H. Ranson we knew at U. M. C.?
If so he is now at Colgates N.Y.
Judge Leland - I suppose - will
be our next Gov. As far as I
know he is a good & pure man.
I shall hear from you again before
your Commencement Closes - if I am
unable to see you at H.
The phenomenal weather has kept me
almost sick for some weeks.
Let me hear from you soon Your friend
J. T. Hand

So, line by line, I see a bit of a discussion about university staffing, and specifically, the "Chain of Ancient Languages". This is a bit unusual. Then, there's a mention of the "Nat. Teachers Association" meeting in Saratoga in July. After that, the writer asks about Professor J. H. Ranton in "Hollingsworths Journal" - and whether he is the same person they knew at "U.M.C." The reference to "U.M.C." is intriguing. It's followed by a statement that he is now at "Colgates N.Y." This is the Colgate University. The letter then moves on to politics, with a comment about "Judge Leland" becoming the next Governor. Seems the writer is located somewhere where Cyrus Leland was influential. The letter ends with typical friendly sentiments and a signature. "J. T. Hand". Now, some of the details are a bit tricky. The handwriting is a little faded and stylized. For instance, the name "Ranton" in line 13 looks slightly different from "Ranson" in line 15, but it could just be handwriting style. Similarly, there is a reference to a `Chain` and `Chair` of languages, this may refer to a sequence or department. The most interesting aspect of the note is the reference to "Colgates N.Y." This is a key detail. The writer seems connected to education. My final analysis of the words is reflected above, preserving the idiosyncrasies of the original.
